original_sentence: Hello, Loora. Nice to meet you. My name is Miguel. I'm from Colombia, Latin America. It's a pleasure to meet you. Thank you.

fragments.error_sentence: I'm from Colombia, Latin America.
fragments.correction_1: I'm from Colombia, in South America.
fragments.correction_2: I'm from Colombia. It's in South America.
fragments.comment: Use 'in South America' or split the sentence. 'Latin America' is broader and less commonly used in intros.

origin.explanation: The speaker used 'Latin America' instead of the more natural 'South America' for introductions.

fragments.advice: Practice saying where you're from using 'I'm from [country]. It's in [continent].' Try 3 countries aloud.

result_sentence_1: Hello, Loora. Nice to meet you. My name is Miguel. I'm from Colombia, in South America. It's a pleasure to meet you. Thank you.
result_sentence_2: Hello, Loora. Nice to meet you. My name is Miguel. I'm from Colombia. It's in South America. It's a pleasure to meet you. Thank you.
say_it_like_a_native_speaker: Hey Loora! I'm Miguel from Colombia — nice to meet you! It's a pleasure. Thanks!

original_sentence: Well, I was born here. I don't know other countries abroad, but I like everything, I think so.

fragments.error_sentence: I don't know other countries abroad
fragments.correction_1: I haven’t been to other countries
fragments.correction_2: I’ve never traveled abroad
fragments.comment: Use 'been to' or 'traveled to' when talking about experience with places, not 'know'.

origin.explanation: In Spanish, 'conocer' implies personal experience, which doesn't translate directly to 'know' in this context.

fragments.advice: Practice 3 new sentences using 'I’ve never been to…' and name real countries. Say them aloud to hear the natural structure.

fragments.error_sentence: I like everything, I think so
fragments.correction_1: I think I like everything
fragments.correction_2: I guess I like most things
fragments.comment: 'I think so' is used to confirm yes/no questions, not to add uncertainty to your own statement.

origin.explanation: The learner used 'I think so' as if it worked like 'I think I do', which is a different function.

fragments.advice: Write 3 opinions using 'I think I…' and say them aloud to get used to that structure in natural speech.

result_sentence_1: Well, I was born here. I haven’t been to other countries, but I think I like everything.
result_sentence_2: Well, I was born here. I’ve never traveled abroad, but I guess I like most things.
say_it_like_a_native_speaker: I’ve lived here all my life. I haven’t traveled much, but honestly, I enjoy everything about this place.

original_sentence: Well, definitely the US, Estados Unidos, because when I was a child, I see a lot of movies about, you know, Disney World, something like that, and I have a good image about them, and one day I want to travel there.

fragments.error_sentence: the US, Estados Unidos
fragments.correction_1: the US
fragments.correction_2: the United States
fragments.comment: Avoid mixing Spanish with English unless the context requires it.

origin.explanation: Switching to Spanish mid-sentence can break fluency and confuse listeners.

fragments.advice: Stick to one language per sentence. Practice saying country names in English.

fragments.error_sentence: I see a lot of movies about
fragments.correction_1: I saw a lot of movies about
fragments.correction_2: I used to watch a lot of movies about
fragments.comment: Use past tense for memories or childhood experiences.

origin.explanation: The speaker used present tense instead of past when talking about childhood.

fragments.advice: Practice 5 memories using 'When I was a child, I watched/saw…'.

fragments.error_sentence: I have a good image about them
fragments.correction_1: I have a good impression of it
fragments.correction_2: I have a nice memory of it
fragments.comment: 'Image about' is unnatural. Use 'impression of' or 'memory of'.

origin.explanation: Likely a direct translation from Spanish 'tengo una buena imagen de...'

fragments.advice: Learn common collocations like 'good impression of'. Write 3 personal examples.

fragments.error_sentence: one day I want to travel there
fragments.correction_1: One day, I’d like to travel there
fragments.correction_2: Someday, I hope to visit
fragments.comment: 'I want to' sounds less natural for expressing future dreams.

origin.explanation: Learners often use 'want to' instead of softer expressions like 'hope to' or 'would like to'.

fragments.advice: Practice 3 future dream sentences using 'I’d like to…'

result_sentence_1: Well, definitely the US, because when I was a child, I saw a lot of movies about Disney World, and I have a good impression of it, and one day I’d like to travel there.
result_sentence_2: Well, definitely the United States, because when I was a child, I used to watch a lot of movies about Disney World, and I have a nice memory of it, and someday I hope to visit.
say_it_like_a_native_speaker: Definitely the US. When I was a kid, I used to watch tons of movies about Disney World, and I’ve always had this great image of it. I really hope I can visit someday.

original_sentence: Well, actually, I don't remember that one because, you know, when I was a child, but the Walt Disney is like a, I don't remember, sorry, like a, movies for kids, you know.

fragments.error_sentence: I don't remember that one because, you know, when I was a child, but
fragments.correction_1: I don’t really remember that one. I was a child back then, you know.
fragments.correction_2: I don’t remember much, because I was just a kid.
fragments.comment: Avoid using 'because' and 'but' together without full clauses. Break it into shorter statements.

origin.explanation: Trying to combine cause and contrast in one sentence caused confusion.

fragments.advice: Practice building short memories using 'because' and 'but' in separate, clear ideas.

fragments.error_sentence: the Walt Disney is like a
fragments.correction_1: Walt Disney is like...
fragments.correction_2: Disney is kind of like...
fragments.comment: Avoid saying 'the Walt Disney'. Use the name without the article.

origin.explanation: In Spanish, 'el Walt Disney' is common, but in English, names like 'Walt Disney' don’t need 'the'.

fragments.advice: Practice saying 5 brand names in English without 'the'. Say them aloud.

fragments.error_sentence: like a, movies for kids
fragments.correction_1: like movies for kids
fragments.correction_2: like children’s movies
fragments.comment: 'A movies' is incorrect — don't use 'a' with plural nouns.

origin.explanation: The learner confused article use with countable plural forms.

fragments.advice: Practice spotting article errors. Say 3 examples using 'a movie' vs 'movies'.

result_sentence_1: Well, actually, I don’t really remember that one. I was a child back then, you know. Walt Disney is like... sorry, like movies for kids.
result_sentence_2: Well, actually, I don’t remember much, because I was just a kid. Disney is kind of like children’s movies, you know.
say_it_like_a_native_speaker: Honestly, I don’t really remember that one — I was just a kid. But Disney? Yeah, it's like classic kids' movies, you know?

original_sentence: Well, I don't remember in particular about Disney, but I remember another movies that I like so much nowadays, like Matrix, for example, it's a good movie, it's like a science fiction action movie.

fragments.error_sentence: I don't remember in particular about Disney
fragments.correction_1: I don’t remember much about Disney in particular
fragments.correction_2: I don’t really remember anything specific about Disney
fragments.comment: The phrase 'in particular about' is awkward and unclear. It needs to be reordered.

origin.explanation: Direct translation from Spanish 'en particular sobre' causes unnatural phrasing in English.

fragments.advice: Say 3 variations of 'I don’t remember much about…' and end with the topic.

fragments.error_sentence: another movies that I like so much nowadays
fragments.correction_1: other movies that I really like now
fragments.correction_2: some more movies I enjoy nowadays
fragments.comment: 'Another' is for singular nouns. Use 'other' for plural.

origin.explanation: Learners often confuse 'another' (singular) with 'other' (plural).

fragments.advice: Practice 3 phrases with 'another' (singular) and 3 with 'other' (plural). Say them aloud.

fragments.error_sentence: it's like a science fiction action movie
fragments.correction_1: it's a science fiction action movie
fragments.correction_2: it's a sci-fi action film
fragments.comment: 'Like a' is unnecessary — just state what it is clearly.

origin.explanation: Repeating similar information instead of integrating it naturally.

fragments.advice: Practice combining ideas like 'It's a [type] movie — it's [quality]'. Try 3 examples aloud.

result_sentence_1: Well, I don’t remember much about Disney in particular, but I remember other movies that I really like now, like The Matrix. It’s a good movie — a science fiction action movie.
result_sentence_2: Well, I don’t really remember anything specific about Disney, but I enjoy some more movies nowadays, like The Matrix. It’s a good sci-fi action film.
say_it_like_a_native_speaker: I don’t really remember much about Disney, but I love movies like The Matrix — such a cool sci-fi action film!

original_sentence: Well, it's so interesting because it's like a reality, well, a little exaggerating reality, but maybe in the future, maybe that happens. I don't know.

fragments.error_sentence: it's like a reality
fragments.correction_1: it's like real life
fragments.correction_2: it's kind of realistic
fragments.comment: 'A reality' sounds unnatural in English. Use 'real life' or 'realistic'.

origin.explanation: The Spanish phrase 'una realidad' is often translated literally as 'a reality', which sounds odd in English.

fragments.advice: Practice using 'real life' and 'realistic' in different example sentences aloud.

fragments.error_sentence: a little exaggerating reality
fragments.correction_1: a slightly exaggerated reality
fragments.correction_2: a bit of an exaggerated version of reality
fragments.comment: Use 'exaggerated' (adjective), not 'exaggerating' (verb form).

origin.explanation: The learner confused the verb with the adjective form.

fragments.advice: Study pairs like 'boring/bored', 'confusing/confused', 'exaggerated/exaggerating'.

fragments.error_sentence: maybe that happens
fragments.correction_1: maybe that will happen
fragments.correction_2: maybe that could happen
fragments.comment: Use future tense when talking about something that might happen later.

origin.explanation: In Spanish, present tense is often used to express future possibility, which doesn't work the same in English.

fragments.advice: Make 3 future predictions starting with 'maybe that will…' or 'maybe it could…'

result_sentence_1: Well, it's so interesting because it's like real life — a slightly exaggerated reality. But maybe in the future, maybe that will happen. I don't know.
result_sentence_2: Well, it's kind of realistic — a bit of an exaggerated version of reality. Who knows? Maybe that could happen one day.
say_it_like_a_native_speaker: It’s super interesting — kind of like real life, just a bit over the top. Honestly, I wouldn’t be surprised if something like that happens in the future.

original_sentence: Lately I saw several movies, like romance movies. I like it as well so much. For example, recently I saw the movie called Before Sunrise. It's like a beautiful movie. I don't know if you know about that movie, Before Sunrise. It's a romance movie.

fragments.error_sentence: Lately I saw several movies
fragments.correction_1: Lately I’ve watched several movies
fragments.correction_2: Recently, I’ve seen several movies
fragments.comment: Use present perfect ('have seen') with 'lately' or 'recently'.

origin.explanation: The learner used past tense with a recent-time adverb, which needs present perfect.

fragments.advice: Practice 5 present perfect sentences with 'lately' or 'recently'.

fragments.error_sentence: I like it as well so much
fragments.correction_1: I really like it too
fragments.correction_2: I like it a lot as well
fragments.comment: The word order is awkward. Use more natural phrases like 'I like it too'.

origin.explanation: Likely a direct transfer from Spanish: 'también me gusta mucho'.

fragments.advice: Say 3 natural variations of this sentence aloud to get the rhythm.

fragments.error_sentence: the movie called Before Sunrise
fragments.correction_1: a movie called Before Sunrise
fragments.correction_2: a film titled Before Sunrise
fragments.comment: Use 'a' when introducing something for the first time.

origin.explanation: Learner used 'the' as if the listener already knew the movie.

fragments.advice: Practice 3 phrases that introduce new movies: 'a movie called…'

fragments.error_sentence: It's like a beautiful movie
fragments.correction_1: It’s a beautiful movie
fragments.correction_2: It’s such a beautiful film
fragments.comment: The word 'like' weakens the statement. Just say it clearly.

origin.explanation: Using 'like' when unsure is common in speech, but not needed here.

fragments.advice: Practice 3 strong statements of opinion: 'It’s a great movie', etc.

result_sentence_1: Lately I’ve watched several movies, like romance movies. I really like them too. For example, I recently saw a movie called Before Sunrise. It’s a beautiful movie. I don’t know if you know it — Before Sunrise. It’s a romance movie.
result_sentence_2: Recently, I’ve seen several movies, including some romantic ones. I like them a lot as well. For instance, I saw a film titled Before Sunrise. It’s such a beautiful film. Do you know it? Before Sunrise. It’s a romance movie.
say_it_like_a_native_speaker: Lately I’ve been watching a bunch of romance movies. I really enjoy them. One that stood out was Before Sunrise — it’s a beautiful film. Have you heard of it?

original_sentence: and another movie that I saw today it was the notebook is another romance movie so beautiful as well

fragments.error_sentence: and another movie that I saw today it was the notebook
fragments.correction_1: Another movie I saw today was The Notebook
fragments.correction_2: I saw The Notebook today — another romantic movie
fragments.comment: The sentence lacks proper structure. Avoid repeating subjects and use clean phrasing.

origin.explanation: Spoken speech often blends ideas. Writing needs clearer structure.

fragments.advice: Practice short clear openings like 'One movie I saw was…'.

fragments.error_sentence: is another romance movie so beautiful as well
fragments.correction_1: It’s another beautiful romance movie
fragments.correction_2: It’s a very beautiful romantic movie too
fragments.comment: The adjective 'beautiful' is in the wrong position. Reorder for natural flow.

origin.explanation: This mirrors Spanish phrasing, which places adjectives differently.

fragments.advice: Say 3 natural variations aloud using 'a beautiful movie' or 'a romantic film'.

result_sentence_1: Another movie I saw today was The Notebook. It’s another beautiful romance movie.
result_sentence_2: I saw The Notebook today — a very beautiful romantic movie too.
say_it_like_a_native_speaker: Today I watched The Notebook. It’s such a beautiful love story — one of my favorites!

original_sentence: well another movie is like before before sunrise before sunrise and in that I remember that is saying that I like it for example it was when the boy tried to go to the girl that I like it and he tried to get up in the rollercoaster not not not really rollercoaster it's like part of the diversions but I don't remember the name of that attraction but it was a little dangerous because he tried to tell her that he wanted to go out with her but he tried to suicide but only joking I don't know if you know about that the same of the before sunrise I think

fragments.error_sentence: another movie is like before before sunrise before sunrise
fragments.correction_1: Another movie is similar to Before Sunrise
fragments.correction_2: It reminds me of Before Sunrise
fragments.comment: Repetition makes it confusing. Use clear comparison phrasing.

origin.explanation: The speaker repeated the phrase trying to recall or emphasize.

fragments.advice: Practice clear comparisons like 'It’s similar to…' or 'It reminds me of…'.

fragments.error_sentence: I remember that is saying that I like it
fragments.correction_1: I remember a scene that I really liked
fragments.correction_2: There’s a part I remember because I liked it
fragments.comment: The sentence is unclear and has grammatical issues.

origin.explanation: Tried to link ideas without a clear clause structure.

fragments.advice: Practice 3 variations with 'I remember a time when…' and say them aloud.

fragments.error_sentence: the boy tried to go to the girl that I like it
fragments.correction_1: The boy tried to approach the girl he liked
fragments.correction_2: He went to the girl he had a crush on
fragments.comment: Tense and subject don’t match. Clarify who liked whom.

origin.explanation: The sentence mixed present and past incorrectly.

fragments.advice: Use past tense for actions in movie scenes. Practice: 'He liked', 'She went', etc.

fragments.error_sentence: he tried to get up in the rollercoaster not not not really rollercoaster it's like part of the diversions
fragments.correction_1: He climbed onto a ride — not a rollercoaster, but something like it
fragments.correction_2: He went up on one of the rides — I don’t remember the name
fragments.comment: 'Diversions' is not the right word in English here.

origin.explanation: In Spanish, 'diversiones' refers to amusement rides, not distractions.

fragments.advice: Learn 5 amusement park nouns: 'ride', 'attraction', 'carousel', etc.

fragments.error_sentence: he tried to suicide but only joking
fragments.correction_1: He pretended to jump, but just as a joke
fragments.correction_2: He acted like he was going to hurt himself — but he was just kidding
fragments.comment: Don't use 'suicide' as a verb. Use softer phrasing for jokes.

origin.explanation: Using 'suicide' as a verb can sound alarming. It’s better to soften emotional actions in English.

fragments.advice: Practice safer ways to say 'he was joking' or 'he acted like…'.

result_sentence_1: Another movie is similar to Before Sunrise. I remember a scene that I really liked — when the boy tried to approach the girl he liked. He climbed onto a ride — not a rollercoaster, but something like it. It was a little dangerous, and he acted like he was going to hurt himself — but just joking.
result_sentence_2: It reminds me of Before Sunrise. There’s a part I remember because I liked it — the boy tried to talk to the girl he had a crush on. He went up on one of the rides — not exactly a rollercoaster, but something similar. It looked risky, and he pretended to jump, but just for fun.
say_it_like_a_native_speaker: It reminded me of Before Sunrise. There was this scene where the guy does something kind of risky to impress the girl — like climbing a ride at a fair or something. He was just being dramatic though — totally joking!

original_sentence: Yes, exactly. It was so impactful that scene because at the same time it was dangerous and funny because the girl, she was so scary about the guy but the guy finally get a... it's made that her pronounce like she wanted to go out with her, you know, like a date and finally the guy achieved her, his purpose with her, and that was funny but yeah a little crazy as well.

fragments.error_sentence: It was so impactful that scene
fragments.correction_1: That scene was so impactful
fragments.correction_2: The scene was really impactful
fragments.comment: The subject and adjective are out of order.

origin.explanation: Follows Spanish sentence rhythm.

fragments.advice: Practice short patterns like: 'That moment was...,' 'This scene was...'

fragments.error_sentence: the girl, she was so scary about the guy
fragments.correction_1: The girl was really scared of the guy
fragments.correction_2: She was so afraid of him
fragments.comment: 'Scary' describes something that causes fear — not a feeling.

origin.explanation: In Spanish, 'asustada' vs. 'asustante' gets mixed up in English as 'scared' vs. 'scary'.

fragments.advice: Practice the difference between 'scary' (thing) and 'scared' (person).

fragments.error_sentence: finally get a... it's made that her pronounce like she wanted to go out with her
fragments.correction_1: He finally made her say she wanted to go out with him
fragments.correction_2: He got her to admit she liked him and wanted a date
fragments.comment: The verbs and pronouns are mixed up and unclear.

origin.explanation: Wrong verbs like 'pronounce' used instead of 'say'.

fragments.advice: Practice structures like 'He made her...', 'She got him to...', etc.

fragments.error_sentence: finally the guy achieved her, his purpose with her
fragments.correction_1: He finally achieved his goal with her
fragments.correction_2: He succeeded in getting what he wanted with her
fragments.comment: You achieve a goal — not a person.

origin.explanation: Probably from 'logró su propósito con ella'.

fragments.advice: Use correct collocations like 'achieve a goal', 'reach success'.

result_sentence_1: That scene was so impactful because it was both dangerous and funny. The girl was really scared of the guy, but in the end, he made her say she wanted to go out with him. He finally achieved his goal with her — it was funny, but also a little crazy.
result_sentence_2: The scene was really impactful — a mix of danger and humor. She was afraid of the guy at first, but eventually, he got her to admit she liked him. He succeeded in getting what he wanted with her. It was kind of wild, but also funny.
say_it_like_a_native_speaker: That scene really stuck with me — it was kind of risky but funny too. The girl was scared at first, but in the end, the guy won her over and got the date. A little crazy, but sweet in a way.

original_sentence: Yeah, you're right. I agree with you.
result_sentence_1: Yeah, you're right. I agree with you.
result_sentence_2: Yes, you’re right — I feel the same way.
say_it_like_a_native_speaker: Totally — I feel the same way!

original_sentence: It's so important to be companion or to be alone for me. It's the same thing for me. I feel good alone and as well if I have company.

fragments.error_sentence: It's so important to be companion or to be alone for me.
fragments.correction_1: It's important for me to have company or be alone.
fragments.correction_2: Whether I have company or I'm alone, it's fine with me.
fragments.comment: Missing article with 'companion' and unnatural contrast structure.

origin.explanation: Likely translated directly from Spanish or simplified construction.

fragments.advice: Practice 'to be a companion' and using 'whether... or...' structures to contrast ideas.

fragments.error_sentence: It's the same thing for me.
fragments.correction_1: It's the same to me.
fragments.correction_2: It doesn't make a difference to me.
fragments.comment: 'Same thing for me' is understandable but not very idiomatic.

origin.explanation: Direct usage of 'same thing' rather than natural expressions like 'I don’t mind'.

fragments.advice: Practice common expressions: 'It’s all the same to me', 'I’m good either way'.

fragments.error_sentence: I feel good alone and as well if I have company.
fragments.correction_1: I feel good whether I'm alone or with company.
fragments.correction_2: I’m comfortable both alone and with others.
fragments.comment: The use of 'as well' is incorrect here. The sentence lacks natural flow.

origin.explanation: No strong command of patterns like 'both... and…' or 'whether... or…'.

fragments.advice: Practice balanced structures for contrast: 'whether... or', 'both... and'.

result_sentence_1: It's important for me to have company or be alone. It's the same to me. I feel good whether I'm alone or with company.
result_sentence_2: Whether I have company or I'm alone, it's fine with me. It doesn't make a difference to me. I'm comfortable both alone and with others.
say_it_like_a_native_speaker: Honestly, I’m fine either way — I enjoy being alone, but I also like having company. It doesn’t really matter to me.
